March 27, 2007


Director, Regulatory Management Division
U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services
Department of Homeland Security
111 Massachusetts Avenue, NW., 3rd Floor
Washington, DC 20529

Re:Proposed Adjustment of the Immigration and Naturalization Benefit
Application and Petition Fee Schedule, DHS Docket Number USCIS 2006-0044

To Whom It May Concern:

This letter is in opposition to the proposed fee increases for the I-600/600A orphan
petitions required of adoptive families.

I recently completed the adoption of a 2 1/2 year old boy from Russia (he became
a U.S. citizen 11/23/06). This was a very expensive and difficult task at current
costs. As a single father, working full time, I could barely afford it, but I
desperately wanted a son. Fortunately, I completed my adoption one month
before my I-600/600A would have expired, or I would have had to redo this form at
even more out of pocket, non-reimbursed expense. Many families I know were not
so lucky.

Why are orphaned children seeking to immigrate to the U.S. given greater scrutiny
than adult foreign workers?

Adoptive parents attempting to learn the status of their petition are almost entirely
ignored directed to a status website which is not updated.

There has been no move by USCIS to assist prospective adoptive parents whose
documents expire while they wait for their child's home country to grant them
approval to travel. These parents are forced to reapply with USCIS, repaying the
same exorbitant fees two and sometimes three additional times, each time
subjecting themselves to the same long and uncertain wait for immigration
approval. What is truly shocking about this is that some offices seem to get
approval very quickly while others delay and delay and delay. If there was a
correllation between how over-burdened they were and how delayed they were, the
fee increase might make sense, but there is no correllation whatsoever.

In this request for an increase in fees, USCIS is not asking for what it needs, it
is asking for what it wants. It claims that this fee increase is designed to
provide for an adequate and sustainable level of investment in staff, in
infrastructure, and processes designed to improve the USCIS ability to administer
the nation's immigration laws. The Bureau justifies these increases by asserting
that this fee rule would provide the necessary resources to maintain these
processing time standards and fund further improvements to USCIS business
operations to continue to reduce processing times while ensuring the appropriate
level of security.

I would be amazed to find out that an internationally-adopted child was a member
of a 'sleeper cell'. The idea that adoptive parents are a threat to national security
is laughable. While we agree with the aims of the Department of Homeland
Security, the additional levels of scrutiny on orphaned children and their
prospective parents is absurd.

While the aims of the department are laudable (reducing identity fraud, improving
service, changing benefit applications from paper to electronic means in order to
streamline the process) forcing adoptive parents to bear the burden of these goals
is unconscionable. .

There is an incorrect picture that parents who adopt internationally must have high
disposable incomes. Far from that, most of us are regular people who take out
extra mortgages, increase our credit card debt and put off buying necessities just
to bring out children home. Increasing the burden on us is not simply unfair, it is
detrimental to the lives of waiting children.

We urge rejection of the current proposal and a new requirement that USCIS
reduce the fee burden on adoptive families, give first priority to I-600/600A
applications, consolidate the paperwork required for orphan petitions, and extend
the expiration of the I-171H from eighteen months to three years.

Sincerely,

Andrew Cronyn
